   Assessment and Plan
   [**Age over 90 **] year old male with a history mild dementia and hypertension who
   presents from home with confusion and inability to perform his
   activities of daily living.  He suffered a fall with head trauma on
   [**2158-2-23**].
   # Altered Mental Status:
   Most likely related to new hemorrhage on CT scan.  Neurologic exam is
   currently non-focal with the exception of disorientation.  Unclear how
   far he is from his baseline.  UA negative.  No WBC count or fevers.  No
   localizing signs of infection.  No new medications.  Mental status
   significantly improves when restraints are removed. Mitts were placed
   overnight to prevent him from harming himself.
   - Attempt to reorient as much as possible
   - Low dose ativan for agitation (avoid haldol given Parkinson's)- will
   check thyroid profile
   - Limit medications which can worsen delerium
   # Intraparenchymal Hemorrhage:
   Right frontal lobe. Neurosurgery consulted in the emergency room,
   recommended repeat CT scan this AM as well as close blood pressure
   monitoring.  Blood pressure elevation highly correlated to agitation.
   Overnight was on nitroprusside drip to maintain SBP < 160.
   - Dose amlodipine 5 mg this AM and attempt to liberate from
   nitroprusside drip
   - Follow-up read on repeat head CT
   - Q4H neuro checks
   - Follow-up speech and swallow evaluation from this AM
   # Hypertension:
   Attempting to maintain SBP <160 as per NSGY. On nitroprusside drip
   overnight as above. Increased amlodipine to 5 mg daily. Attempt
   liberation from nitroprusside today.
   # [**Last Name (un) 5620**] Disease:
   Stable.  Increased tone and cog wheeling on exam.
   - Continue sinemet
   # Hypothyroidism:
   - Continue synthroid
   - Follow-up TSH
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Initiate diet per speech and swallow recs
   Glycemic Control:  None needed at this time
   Lines:
   20 Gauge - [**2158-2-28**] 10:40 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: Heparin subcutaneous
   Stress ulcer: None indicated
   Communication:  Wife: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 5621**] (c) [**Telephone/Fax (1) 5622**] (h)
   Code status: DNR/DNI
   Disposition: Call-out to floor pending CT head and liberation from
   nitroprusside drip
Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 90-year-old male with a history of mild dementia, hypertension, and Parkinson's disease who presented with confusion and an inability to perform activities of daily living after a fall with head trauma. He has an altered mental status, likely related to a new hemorrhage on the CT scan, and no signs of infection. His neurological exam is non-focal except for disorientation. He is currently on a low dose of ativan for agitation and is being monitored closely. He has an intraparenchymal hemorrhage in the right frontal lobe, and neurosurgery recommended a repeat CT scan this morning as well as close blood pressure monitoring. His blood pressure elevation is highly correlated with agitation, so he was on a nitroprusside drip overnight to maintain SBP < 160. The plan is to liberate him from the nitroprusside drip today and follow up with a read on the repeat head CT. He has a history of hypertension, Parkinson's disease, and hypothyroidism, and his medications will be continued as before. The patient's condition is stable, and he will initiate diet per speech and swallow recommendations. He is on prophylaxis for DVT and stress ulcer, and his code status is DNR/DNI.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 90-year-old male with a history of mild dementia and hypertension. He presented with confusion and inability to perform activities of daily living after a fall with head trauma on [date]. The patient has an altered mental status, which is most likely related to a new hemorrhage on the CT scan. Neurologic exam is non-focal with disorientation. Mental status improves when restraints are removed. The patient has been diagnosed with an intraparenchymal hemorrhage and hypertension. He also has Parkinson's disease, hypothyroidism, and a history of falls. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Increased intracranial pressure due to the hemorrhage.
2. Neurological deficits or worsening of current symptoms due to the hemorrhage.
3. Hypotension or shock if there is significant blood loss.
4. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism due to immobility.
5. Pressure ulcers or skin breakdown due to prolonged immobility.
6. Aspiration pneumonia due to impaired swallowing and cough reflex.
7. Delirium or worsening of mental status due to medication side effects or metabolic disturbances.
8. Cardiac complications such as arrhythmias or heart failure in the context of hypertension and potential stress on the cardiovascular system.
9. Infection such as urinary tract infection (UTI) or wound infection due to catheterization and potential breach in sterile technique.
10. Poor glycemic control

- The patient is a 90-year-old male with a history of mild dementia and hypertension.

- Nitroprusside drip has been stopped.
- He is currently on amlodipine and captopril for hypertension.
- His mental status has improved significantly with restraints removed.
- He has passed speech and swallow evaluation.
- Supportive management for intraparenchymal hemorrhage is ongoing.
- He is being reoriented and given low-dose ativan for agitation.
- Other medical conditions such as Parkinson's disease, hypothyroidism, and hypertension are stable.
- He is on sinemet for Parkinson's disease and synthroid for hypothyroidism.
- His diet is regular with nectar-thickened liquids and he can take pills whole or crushed with puree.
- Prophylactic measures include pneumoboots.
- His code status is DNR/DNI.
- He will continue to receive ICU care.

1. Increased risk of intracranial pressure due to intraparenchymal hemorrhage.
2. Possibility of further neurological decline or worsening of mental status.
3. Potential complications related to hypertension, such as stroke or heart failure.

Summary:
The patient is a 57-year-old male with a chief complaint of acute confusion. The patient has been admitted to the ICU due to hypertension, intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH), and acute confusion. The patient's vital signs are as follows: temperature 37.4°C (99.4°F), heart rate 94 bpm (with a range of 62-94 bpm), blood pressure 170/89 mmHg (with a range of 111/63-186/112 mmHg), respiratory rate 11 breaths per minute (with a range of 11-39 breaths per minute), and oxygen saturation 99%. The patient is on nitroprusside infusion at 0.5 mcg/kg/min and has been weaned off ni...
Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypertensive emergency or malignant hypertension due to elevated blood pressure.
2. Increased risk of bleeding or rebleeding from the intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) due to the patient's current use of anticoagulants (heparin sodium).
3. Acute kidney injury (AKI) or worsening renal function due to hypotension and potential hypoperfusion of the kidneys.
4. Development of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism (PE) due to prolonged immobilization in the ICU.
5. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to mechanical ventilation.
6. Nosocom

   [**Age over 90 **] year old male with a history mild dementia and hypertension who
   presents from home with confusion and inability to perform his
   activities of daily living found to have an intraparenchymal and
   subdural hemorrhage.
   .
   Altered Mental Status:  Most likely related to new hemorrhage on CT
   scan.  Neurologic exam is currently non-focal with the exception of
   disorientation.  Unclear how far he is from his baseline.  UA
   negative.  No WBC count or fevers.  No localizing signs of infection.
   No new medications.  Mental status significantly improves when
   restraints are removed.
   - management as above for intraparenchymal hemorrhage.
   - attempt to reorient as much as possible
   - low dose ativan for aggitation (avoid haldol given Parkinson's)- will
   check thyroid profile
   - limit medications which can worsen delerium
   .
   Intraparenchymal Hemorrhage:  Neurosurgery consulted in the emergency
   room, recommended repeat CT scan in AM as well as close blood pressure
   monitoring.  Blood pressure elevation highly correlated to agitation.
   - nitroprusside drip for SBP < 160
   - amlodipine increased to 5 mg daily
   - limit use of restraints as much as possible
   - low dose ativan for agitation
   - repeat CT scan in the AM
   - Q4H neuro checks
   - speech and swallow evaluation in the AM
   .
   Hypertension:  As above, at home only on amlodipine 2.5 mg daily.
   Blood pressure worsned by agitation.
   - amlodipine 5 mg daily
   - nitroprusside gtt for SBP < 160
   .
   [**Last Name (un) 5620**] Disease:  Stable.  Increased tone and cog wheeling on exam.
   - continue sinemet
   .
   Hypothyroidism:
   - continue synthroid
   - check TSH
   .
   FEN: No IVF, monitor electrolytes, NPO for now pending swallow eval
   .
   Access: peripherals
   .
   Prophylaxis:  SC heparin
   .
   Code: DNR/DNI
   .
   Communication:  Wife: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 5621**] (c) [**Telephone/Fax (1) 5622**] (h)
   .
   Disposition: ICU care for now

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 90-year-old male with a history of mild dementia and hypertension who presented with confusion and inability to perform activities of daily living. He was found to have an intraparenchymal and subdural hemorrhage. The patient's blood pressure elevation is highly correlated with agitation, and he has been on amlodipine 5 mg daily. His altered mental status is most likely related to the new hemorrhage on the CT scan. The patient's neurologic exam is non-focal with the exception of disorientation. He has passed speech and swallow evaluation. The plan includes supportive management for the intraparenchymal hemorrhage, attempting to reorient as much as possible, using low-dose ativan for agitation, limiting medications that can worsen delirium, and continuing sinemet for Parkinson's disease. The patient also has stable hypertension and hypothyroidism, for which he is already on appropriate medication. In the ICU, he is receiving regular diet with nectar-thickened liquids and crushed pills with puree. He has two IV lines, prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis and stress ulcers, and is on DNR/DNI status. The patient will continue to receive ICU care, and social work has been involved. 

Potential medical complications that can arise:
1. Increased intracranial pressure due to the presence of intraparenchymal and subdural hemorrhages.
2. Hypotension and shock if there is significant blood loss or if antihypertensive medications lead to a drop in blood pressure.
3. Infection due to prolonged hospitalization and use of indwelling lines or devices.
4. Thrombosis of the deep veins due to immobility and presence of a central venous catheter.
5. Gastric ulcers or stress ulcers due to prolonged critical illness and immobilization.
6. Ventilator-associated pneumonia due to prolonged intubation and immobilization.
7. Further deterioration in mental status or development of delirium.
8. Worsening of hypertension or hypotension.
9. Development of renal insufficiency or acute kidney injury due to decreased urine output.
10. Malnutrition due to decreased oral intake and inability to eat normally.
11. Pressure ulcers due to prolonged immobility and pressure on bony prominences.
12. Deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism due to immobility and hypercoagulable state.

Please note that this is a summary of the patient's condition and potential complications. The actual clinical situation may vary, and additional information from the patient's medical history, physical examination, and diagnostic tests would be required to provide a comprehensive assessment.

   Assessment and Plan
   [**Age over 90 **] year old male with a history mild dementia and hypertension who
   presents from home with confusion and inability to perform his
   activities of daily living found to have an intraparenchymal and
   subdural hemorrhage.
   # Intraparenchymal Hemorrhage:
   Neurosurgery consulted in the emergency room, recommended repeat CT
   scan, which showed stable bleed, as well as close blood pressure
   monitoring.  Blood pressure elevation highly correlated to agitation.
   Nitroprusside drip now off and nitro paste not needed at this time.
   - cont amlodipine 5 mg, captopril 50 mg three times daily for BP
   control
   - limit use of restraints as much as possible
   - low dose ativan for agitation (has not needed this recently)
   - neuro checks
   #Altered Mental Status:
   Patient is likely at his baseline. Not oriented to place or exact date.
   Struggles from sun-downing. Verbal redirection has been adequate. Has
   passed speech and swallow eval.
   - attempt to reorient as much as possible
   - low dose ativan for aggitation (avoid haldol given Parkinson's),
   though has not yet been needed
   - limit medications which can worsen delerium
   #Hypertension:
   At home only on amlodipine 2.5 mg daily.  Blood pressure worsned by
   agitation. Off nitroprusside gtt. No nitro paste requirement at this
   time. On amlodipine and captopril.
   - amlodipine 5 mg daily, and captopril 50 three times daily
   - Nitropaste only as needed to keep SBP < 160
   - Discontinue nitroprusside

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 90-year-old male with a history of mild dementia and hypertension. He presented to the hospital with confusion and an inability to perform daily activities. He was found to have an intraparenchymal and subdural hemorrhage. Neurosurgery recommended close blood pressure monitoring, and nitroprusside drip was stopped. The patient's blood pressure elevation is highly correlated with agitation. He is currently on amlodipine and captopril for blood pressure control. He is also experiencing altered mental status, likely at his baseline, with struggles from sundowning. Verbal redirection has been effective so far. He has passed a speech and swallow evaluation. The plan includes reorientation, low-dose ativan for agitation, and limiting medications that can worsen delirium. He has hypertension, Parkinson's disease, and hypothyroidism, all of which are being managed accordingly. The patient's current ICU care includes regular diet with nectar-thickened liquids and crushed medications. He has two IV lines in place, prophylaxis for DVT and stress ulcers, and VAP precautions. The patient's wife has been informed, and he has a DNR/DNI code status with a possible transfer to rehab from the ICU.
